sub_title: Institutional Researcher at Liverpool John Moores University

projects.title: Getting Rid of Litter(ing): ‘Boosting’ Dutch Vmbo-Student’s Selective Attention to Increase Correct Waste Disposal Behaviour
projects.description:
To reduce littering and increase correct waste disposal behaviour among Dutch first- and second-year
vocational education (vmbo) students, this study aimed to ‘boost’ their selective attention towards
waste items and bins. ‘Boosting’ is a behaviour change approach that entails teaching people
competencies that can be applied across contexts and situations. An online training program was
designed in which psychological constructs (e.g. self-efficacy, etc.) were expected to influence vmbo students’ goal to engage in correct waste disposal behaviour. Furthermore, various exercises were
expected to enhance the development of competencies to reduce cognitive load. The combination was
expected to ‘boost’, and hence, increase vmbo-students’ selective attention. Nevertheless, the results
indicated that vmbo-students whose selective attention was ‘boosted’ (N = 63) did not score higher on
the psychological constructs than students in the control condition (N = 75). Moreover, the students
whose selective attention was ‘boosted’ did neither continue longer with waste disposal nor correctly
dispose of waste items more often than students in the control condition. Nevertheless, explorative
analyses did indicate that providing students with information on the consequences of littering
increases their knowledge, makes students believe more that others consider correct waste disposal
important and makes them consider it as more important themselves as well. While these findings do
not yet translate to an increase in correct waste disposal behaviour, this study does offer concrete
starting points to further investigate the potential of ‘boosting’ students’ selective attention to create
sustainable behaviour change which transfers to various contexts and situations.

contributors.headline: Institutional Researcher at Liverpool John Moores University

projects.title: A High School Teacher’s Commitment to Change: the Influence of Bias caused by Anchoring
projects.description:
Developing a high school teacher’s commitment to change is of importance in order to reach educational change. It is still commonly believed that this process is accompanied by a rational decision-making process, but research suggests otherwise. This experiment, therefore, aimed at proving the effect of bias caused by anchoring on high school teachers’ (affective, normative and continuance) commitment to change. Differences in gender and work experience were investigated as well. A total of 195 high school teachers in the Netherlands participated in the experiment. The teachers were assigned to three different conditions (no anchor, an encouraging anchor or a discouraging anchor) to possibly manipulate the outcomes. The results indicated that high school teachers that were presented with an encouraging anchor scored higher on normative commitment to change than teachers that were presented with a discouraging anchor. Furthermore, high school teachers with more than three years of work experience in the control condition scored higher on continuance commitment to change than teachers with less than or three years of work experience in the control condition. Even though fewer effects of anchoring were found than expected, the anchors in combination with the scenario might have elicited an unconscious normative influence. Thus, the results do provide evidence to suggest that high school teachers might not be as rational in their decision-making processes towards change as is still commonly assumed. Suggested is to take the role of familiarity, knowledge or expertise with the proposed changes into account when conducting future research. 
Keywords: change management, affective, normative, continuance, commitment to change, bias, anchoring, high school teacher, gender, work experience

contributors.headline: Institutional Researcher at Liverpool John Moores University

projects.title: Bystander Presence and the Mental Well-Being of Male and Female Victims of Sexual Harassment
projects.description:
A lot of research is done about the ‘bystander effect’. Less is known about the effect of the number of
passive bystanders. This research aims at investigating the effect of the number of passive bystanders on the mental well-being of a victim of sexual harassment. Students ranging from the age of 18 to 25 were asked to participate in this study. With using Virtual Reality videos, it was tried to come as close to a real life situation as possible. Before and after the video, the students answered multiple questions about mental well-being, which was measured in terms of multiple concepts. The effect of the number of bystanders on the need for safety, one of the constructs of mental well-being, of a victim of sexual harassment was found to be significant (p = .048). The score on need for safety tends to be higher when there are less bystanders present, which implies a lower mental well-being when less bystanders are present. Additionally, the effect of ‘just world beliefs’ on the mental well-being was investigated as well.  he study showed that self-blame thoughts (p = .010), one of the other concepts of which mental well- being consists, tend to be higher when someone scores low on ‘just world beliefs’ and more bystanders re present. No other significant effects were found for both the main research questions and the additional research questions about ‘just world beliefs’. The quality and severity of the Virtual Reality video might be a reason for the low amount of significant effects found. For future research suggestions have been made to improve the quality of the video, since it remains an important subject to investigate to be able to help future victims of sexual harassment in an appropriate and scientific proven way.
Keywords: bystander effect, sexual harassment, number of bystanders, Virtual Reality, just world beliefs

contributors.headline: Institutional Researcher at Liverpool John Moores University

profile_positions.description:
As an Institutional Researcher for the Teaching & Learning Academy, I support the collection, analysis and communication of institutional data, including University survey outcomes.

Furthermore, in this role, I am involved in the design and co-ordination of research and evaluation work associated with the University's Learning, Teaching, Assessment strategy and Access and Participation Plan. This includes analysing institutional datasets (qualitative and quantitative) related to the student experience from pre-enrolment to graduation (e.g. recruitment data, performance data, satisfaction surveys) in order to implement and evaluate the impact of the institutional interventions.
profile_positions.title: Institutional Researcher

profile_positions.description: As a research assistant at So-Mo, my main responsibility is conducting user research for our clients in the public sector. The insights gathered are used to inform policy, communications, and service design with behavioural analyses, intervention design, evaluation, data analysis, report writing, presentations, workshops and training. As a Behavioural Science Consultancy, our aim is to use behavioural science to help people to make different choices and build better habits. Collectively these small changes achieve a big impact!
profile_positions.title: Research Assistant

profile_positions.description: As a BSc psychology teacher (B1, B2, B3), I am part of the department Psychology of Conflict, Risk and Safety. Any research projects I am guiding, are applied to that field of research. My main tasks involve: guiding students during projects focused on systematically designing interventions for psychological problems in society, teaching students basic psychological conversation skills, as well as communication skills in a group setting, guiding third-year BSc thesis students in their process of working on their final research project to graduate, guiding second-year psychology students in their process of conducting and reporting quantitative research, and finally, guiding a project group working for a real client in conducting research and constructing an advisory report as part of a minor (Educational Science & Technology).
profile_positions.title: Teacher Psychology

profile_positions.description: Leading the study association B-Change, with as main tasks the guidance of committees, the organisation of events and activities, and the maintenance of the social media accounts and the website of B-Change.
profile_positions.title: Board year B-Change - Head of Media

profile_positions.description: The coming half a year, I will be working as a(n) (intern) behavioural psychologist at De Bries, in order to reduce littering behaviour of youngsters in the municipality of Altena. By means of scientific research and behaviour change techniques is aimed to develop a creative intervention to reach the final goal: a reduction of litter!
profile_positions.title: Master's internship as behavioural psychologist

profile_positions.description: As a student mentor, the main tasks are to inform first-year psychology students about practical information in relation to the bachelor Psychology and student life in Enschede/the University of Twente, answering questions from these students, supporting them with tips and tricks regarding study methods, and having individual conversations about the rules regarding the Binding Recommendation (BSA). The team of student mentors meets on a regular basis to discuss the preparation and progress of individual conversations and classes organised.
profile_positions.title: Student mentor

profile_positions.description: As a tutor of this subject, I guide second-year psychology students during tutorials and practicals in their development of basic psychological communication skills. This course is based on the idea of 'attunement' and the three conditions of Roger's client-centered approach: unconditional positive regard, genuineness, and empathy. In the second half of this course, group dynamics and each individuals' awareness of their self-presentation in groups will be at the centre of attention.
profile_positions.title: Tutor Communication Skills

profile_positions.description: I took over the last weeks of project guidance because of pregnancy leave of one of the tutors in the module 'Social Behaviour'. In these project meetings, I guided the first-year psychology students in their development of a systematical psychological intervention design for aggression in the workplace, at home or during sports. For this, the students were provided with weekly feedback on their project report and were regular meetings with the team of tutors planned to discuss the main feedback points, progress, etc. Finally, I graded the final project reports and reflection papers of those students.
profile_positions.title: Tutor Social Behaviour

profile_positions.description: Guiding students in the writing of a research paper, in which they have to execute statistical tests like t-tests, regression analyses and correlations. I provided students with weekly feedback on parts of their research paper and was present during tutorials to answer questions. Finally, I graded the final research papers of these students.
profile_positions.title: Student assistent Research Studio (subject of the pre-master of Educational Science and Technology)

profile_positions.description: Providing first-year psychology students with tutorials about systematic psychological design, including theoretical knowledge and practical assignments. The aim is for the students to gain insight into the systematic design during the development of an intervention for a psychological problem. The ASCE-model and belonging concepts were at the core of this systematic design. These tutorials provide the students with the basic knowledge and skills needed for the first project they will engage in.
profile_positions.title: Teacher Systematic Psychological Design

profile_positions.description: Guiding second-year psychology students during the classes of 'communication skills' at the University of Twente. Meetings with the team of teachers about the content and progress of this course were included.
profile_positions.title: Student assistent Communication Skills

profile_positions.description: The 'student services' provides students of the University of Twente with information about all kinds of study-related questions. This includes information about admission and registration, tuition fees, student cards and Studielink.
profile_positions.title: Student services

profile_positions.description:
Welcoming and informing visitors of the Apenheul, checking of entrance tickets and processing e-tickets, handing out and taking in monkey-free bags (for protection personal belongings), supporting in managing employees, opening and closing of the department, controlling carrousel and guiding visitors in this process, cleaning services, working at the ticket office and souvenir shop.

Promotion: more responsibility, directing employees and training new employees.
profile_positions.title: Customer services

profile_positions.description: Taking interested soon-to-be students under my guidance for a day at the University of Twente, including following lectures, showing them around campus and answering questions.
profile_positions.title: Student guide for students-for-a-day

profile_positions.description: Welcoming and informing visitors of the Apenheul, checking of entrance tickets and processing e-tickets, handing out and taking in monkey-free bags (for protection personal belongings), opening and closing of the department, controlling carrousel and guiding visitors in this process, cleaning services, working at the ticket office and souvenir shop.
profile_positions.title: Customer services
